title: 110_s568
content: The Act may be cited as the "Truth in Video Game Rating Act" and includes definitions for key terms. The Act, known as the "Truth in Video Game Rating Act," defines terms like content rating, hidden content, and playable content in video or computer games. Content rating informs individuals about potentially offensive or age-inappropriate content, hidden content is accessible through codes or modifications, and playable content refers to scenes or visuals in the game. The "Truth in Video Game Rating Act" defines terms related to video or computer games, including hidden content, playable content, and content rating. Hidden content can be accessed by users through codes or modifications, playable content refers to scenes or visuals in the game, and content rating is assigned by organizations like the Entertainment Software Ratings Board. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON DECEPTIVE RATINGS OF VIDEO GAMES. Effective 1 year after the enactment of this Act, a rating organization must review the entire playable content of a video or computer game before assigning a content rating. Additionally, producers, sellers, or distributors of video games in interstate commerce are prohibited from withholding or hiding playable content from the rating organization. Effective 1 year after the enactment of this Act, a rating organization must review the entire playable content of a video or computer game before assigning a content rating. Producers, sellers, or distributors are required to provide necessary codes or methods to access hidden content in the game. A rating organization is prohibited from grossly mischaracterizing the content of a video or computer game. The Federal Trade Commission must define "grossly mischaracterizes" within a year of this Act's enactment for video or computer games. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. Violations of prohibitions in section 3 are treated as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Federal Trade Commission enforces this Act as if it were part of the FTC Act. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study within 180 days to evaluate the Entertainment Software Ratings Board system for video and computer games. The study will assess the efficacy of the current rating system, consider peer-review for ratings, and explore the potential benefits of an independent content ratings system. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress within 180 days on the effectiveness of a universal ratings system for visual content, including online video games. Recommendations will address unique challenges of content ratings for online and Internet-based games.
